title: Question 27

children: A 42-year-old man is evaluated for premature ejaculation. He reports that during sexual intercourse, he ejaculates within 30 seconds after vaginal penetration, which causes him significant psychological distress. He has no decrease in libido or difficulty maintaining an erection. Medical history is positive for depressive symptoms predating the onset of premature ejaculation. He takes no medications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
Premature ejaculation is defined as ejaculation with minimal stimulation that occurs earlier than desired; treatment is indicated if associated with psychological distress.

Paroxetine monotherapy or combined with a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor is considered first-line treatment for premature ejaculation; complete therapeutic effect is reached within 2 to 3 weeks of use.

). This patient has premature ejaculation, which is defined as ejaculation with minimal stimulation that occurs earlier than desired. Premature ejaculation that causes self-reported psychological distress in the patient or partner is an indication for treatment. The diagnosis of premature ejaculation is solely based on history. Clinicians should obtain a thorough sexual history (frequency of premature ejaculation, antecedent sexual activities, aggravating and alleviating factors, the impact of premature ejaculation, and any concomitant erectile dysfunction). Assessment for an underlying mood condition is also imperative, given the association between premature ejaculation and development of poor self-esteem and depression. Although the specific pathophysiologic mechanism of premature ejaculation is unknown, dysfunction of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) receptors and penile hypersensitivity are believed to be involved. Paroxetine and other selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are considered first-line therapy and are the most appropriate pharmacologic management option for this patient. A meta-analysis of available trials suggests that paroxetine may be the most effective SSRI. Complete therapeutic response typically occurs within 2 to 3 weeks of continuous use. Owing to upregulation of 5-HT receptors, therapeutic benefit may decline after 6 to 12 months. The combination of a SSRI plus a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor may be the most effective treatment for premature ejaculation but is associated with more side effects than monotherapies.

Clomipramine can be used when SSRIs are either ineffective or not tolerated, but it would be inappropriate to initiate clomipramine in this patient before a trial of paroxetine.
